notes.text: This product is provided subject to this Notification (https://www.cisa.gov/notification) and this Privacy & Use policy (https://www.cisa.gov/privacy-policy).
notes.title: Legal Notice and Terms of Use

notes.text: Successful exploitation of these vulnerabilities could allow an attacker to gain high-level access to and remotely operate the device, potentially putting it into a non-functional state.
notes.title: Risk evaluation

notes.text: Commercial Facilities, Energy, Government Services and Facilities, Healthcare and Public Health, Transportation Systems
notes.title: Critical infrastructure sectors

notes.text: CISA recommends users take defensive measures to minimize the risk of exploitation of these vulnerabilities, such as:
notes.title: Recommended Practices

notes.text: Minimize network exposure for all control system devices and/or systems, ensuring they are not accessible from the internet.
notes.title: Recommended Practices

notes.text: Locate control system networks and remote devices behind firewalls and isolating them from business networks.
notes.title: Recommended Practices

notes.text: When remote access is required, use more secure methods, such as Virtual Private Networks (VPNs), recognizing VPNs may have vulnerabilities and should be updated to the most current version available. Also recognize VPN is only as secure as the connected devices.
notes.title: Recommended Practices

notes.text: CISA reminds organizations to perform proper impact analysis and risk assessment prior to deploying defensive measures.
notes.title: Recommended Practices

notes.text: CISA also provides a section for control systems security recommended practices on the ICS webpage on cisa.gov/ics. Several CISA products detailing cyber defense best practices are available for reading and download, including Improving Industrial Control Systems Cybersecurity with Defense-in-Depth Strategies.
notes.title: Recommended Practices

notes.text: CISA encourages organizations to implement recommended cybersecurity strategies for proactive defense of ICS assets.
notes.title: Recommended Practices

notes.text: Additional mitigation guidance and recommended practices are publicly available on the ICS webpage at cisa.gov/ics in the technical information paper, ICS-TIP-12-146-01B--Targeted Cyber Intrusion Detection and Mitigation Strategies.
notes.title: Recommended Practices

notes.text: Organizations observing suspected malicious activity should follow established internal procedures and report findings to CISA for tracking and correlation against other incidents.
notes.title: Recommended Practices

notes.text: No known public exploitation specifically targeting these vulnerabilities has been reported to CISA at this time. These vulnerabilities are not exploitable remotely.
notes.title: Recommended Practices

document.title: Consilium Safety CS5000 Fire Panel (Update A)

revision_history.summary: Update A - Changed CVSS vectors from AV:N to AV:L and changed the scores to reflect this. Updated the versions affected and additional mitigation details were added. Consilium software version R1.17.1 is now available for the CS5000 Fire Panel.

cwe.name: Initialization of a Resource with an Insecure Default

notes.text: The CS5000 Fire Panel is vulnerable due to a default account that exists on the panel. Even though it is possible to change this by SSHing into the device, it has remained unchanged on every installed system observed. This account is not root but holds high-level permissions that could severely impact the device's operation if exploited.
notes.title: Vulnerability Summary

remediations.details: Consilium Safety has released software version R1.17.1 for the CS5000 Fire Panel. Users should contact their local Consilium office for assistance with applying the update.

Due to the nature of Consilium systems and their deployment in controlled OT environments, software updates are not published for public download. Asset owners should obtain version R1.17.1 through their normal Consilium representative or local support office to ensure the correct package and installation instructions are provided.

Security configuration and hardening recommendations reflecting the changes in R1.17.1 will be provided directly to asset owners as part of the product documentation. These documents are not available as public download links.

Asset owners who want enhanced security features are advised to upgrade to Consilium Safety's newer line of fire panels. Specifically, products manufactured after July 1, 2024, incorporate more secure-by-design principles.
Owners of the CS5000 Fire Panel are recommended to implement compensating countermeasures, such as physical security and access control restrictions for dedicated personnel.
More product safety information can be found on Consilium Safety's support webpage.

notes.text: The CS5000 Fire Panel is vulnerable due to a hard-coded password that runs on a VNC server and is visible as a string in the binary responsible for running VNC. This password cannot be altered, allowing anyone with knowledge of it to gain remote access to the panel. Such access could enable an attacker to operate the panel remotely, potentially putting the fire panel into a non-functional state and causing serious safety issues.
notes.title: Vulnerability Summary

remediations.details: Consilium Safety has released software version R1.17.1 for the CS5000 Fire Panel. Users should contact their local Consilium office for assistance with applying the update.

Due to the nature of Consilium systems and their deployment in controlled OT environments, software updates are not published for public download. More product safety information can be found on Consilium Safety's support webpage.
